jonathansiddharth wrote:
> Thanks Gordon for your reply.
> 
> I was using a bunch of decide rules and one of them was discarding
> hops greater than 2. That might explain a whole lot of URLs being
> discarded very quickly towards the end of the crawl and hence an
> 'abrupt' end to the crawl..I guess. Do you think that's possible?

Maybe, but: the decide-rules are applied even before URLs are 
scheduled, so I wouldn't expect to see a low percent-complete 
number (high 'queued' URL count) that's quickly changed by the 
hops-count rule to end the crawl. (Only if you changed the scope 
rules mid-crawl would once-scheduled URLs then be rejected.)

If you set global crawl limits ('max-bytes-download', 
'max-document-download', 'max-time-sec'), that's checked separate 
from URL scheduling -- so it could cause a crawl to end abruptly 
even while many URLs were waiting.

In no case, though, should the UI show a job as 'finished' and the 
logs/reports still show progress on multiple checks.

- Gordon @ IA
